section.title: Destination Based Injection
Resource Configuration
section.para:
You can use the @JmsSession annotation when injecting javax.jms.Session to specify transacted and acknowledgement mode:
@Inject @JmsSession(transacted=false, acknowledgementMode=Session.CLIENT_ACKNOWLEDGE) Session s;

section.title: Module Extensions
section.para: The Seam JMS module has certain points of extension, where the application developer can customize the behavior to match their needs. This is done by extending any of three base classes:

This can be done using CDI specializations and extending the base class to change the produced object. This allows the application developer to customize the produced behavior. For example, the base implementation assumes a Java EE container, however an extension to the JmsConnectionFactoryProducer could bootstrap a JMS container for you or change the default JNDI location of the ConnectionFactory

tip.para: Extending JmsConnectionFactoryProducer to bootstrap a SE compliant JMS container will be provided out of the box in the next release, supporting HornetQ, OpenMQ and ActiveMQ.

section.para: Each producer in these classes generates an instance based on The @JmsDefault annotation. This object is used within other places of the API, so you can control the Session generated that is injected into a MessageManager this way.
